title: How to Get to the Top of Google in a Featured Snippet
real_title: How to Get to the Top of Google in a Featured Snippet
summary: While organic traffic is becoming more competitive and Google’s algorithms keep evolving, it is more important than ever for website owners to take action and not lose their rankings.
body:
While organic traffic is becoming more competitive and Google’s algorithms keep evolving, it is more important than ever for website owners to take action and not lose their rankings. One way is to take advantage of Googles featured snippet.

## What are Featured Snippets?

When someone runs a search query in Google, sometimes a result will show up in a block at the top of the results. This block is called a featured snippet also known as a quick answer box. 

Included in the snippet is a link to the webpage, a summary of the search result, the title of the page, and the URL. They appear on the top of organic search below the paid ads. 

SEOs strive to get ranked #1 for a search phrase, however, getting content as a featured snippet on Google is even better as it is [considered to be position O](https://www.vazoola.com/resources/white-paper/new-for-2018-the-ultimate-link-building-guide). 

If you can get your content into a Google featured snippet, not only will you increase your visibility, you will get a [higher organic click-through rate](https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-featured-snippet-box).

## How do Featured Snippets Affect SEO?

Google searches bring up featured snippets before other organic results. Many people don’t go beyond the featured snippet resulting in much less traffic and fewer clicks to everything else on the first page.  

What this means is that SEOs need to expand their focus on getting their content to show up as a featured snippet to maintain their search traffic.

## What are the Different Types of Snippets?

There are primarily four types of snippets: 

XXXParagraph

This is the most common type providing direct answers to search queries. It’s best to phrase your content in the form of a question such as:

* How to…
* How does…
* What is…
* How do…

XXXList-based

When searchers are looking for a set of steps to get something done, Google will show the query responses in a numbered list snippet. Examples of search terms that can be used to get featured in a numbered list are:

* Clean out your furnace
* How to get your home ready for sale
* How do you properly wash a car

Notice that sometimes snippets for “how to” and “how do” and similar phrases are list-based and other times they are paragraphs or videos. 

XXXTables

Tables are often used for lists, statistics, and pricing. Google will sometimes [pull only the most useful information](https://www.oberlo.com/blog/google-featured-snippet) from a page and create its own table in answer to a user’s query.

XXXYouTube

YouTube videos are also pulled into featured snippets so be sure to optimize your videos as well. For example, you can answer your target audiences’ questions in the text of your video description and in the title. 

## Which Type is Best?

Depending upon the niche your business is in, will help you determine which type of snippet is best suited for you. 

For example, local businesses should try to get positioned for Google maps results. [Stat Search Analytics](https://getstat.com/blog/featured-snippets/) found that featured snippets do not appear in the SERPs that display the [local pack](https://searchengineland.com/google-updates-the-local-pack-showing-3-instead-of-7-local-results-227368) instead.

If you are in a market that has a need for specific answers to frequently asked questions, you can use your niche-specific terms that provide an explanation or present your data in a table format.

Ben Goodsell from SearchEngineLand.com reports that the click-through rate (CTR) on a webpage that has a [featured snippet increases from 2% to 8%](https://www.oberlo.com/blog/google-featured-snippet). This jump in CTA increases organic traffic by 677%.

## Start with Keyword Research

Aherf reports that [99.58% of featured snippets](https://ahrefs.com/blog/featured-snippets-study/) are pulled from pages that are already in the top 10 ranking positions in the SERPs.

Moz reports that most featured snippets are [triggered by long-tail keywords](https://moz.com/blog/optimize-featured-snippets) as was found in many studies.
